description: From Middle English lien, liggen, from Old English liƒãƒ°an, from Proto-West Germanic *liggjan, from Proto-Germanic *ligjanƒÖ, from Proto-Indo-European *leg ∞-.

Cognate with West Frisian lizze, Dutch liggen, German liegen, Danish and Norwegian Bokm√•l ligge, Swedish ligga, Icelandic, Faroese and Norwegian Nynorsk liggja, Gothic êåªêåπêå≤êå∞êåΩ (ligan); and with Latin lectus (‚Äúbed‚Äù), Irish luighe, Russian –ª–µ–∂–∞ÃÅ—Ç—å (le≈æ√°t π), Albanian lag (‚Äútroop, band, encampment‚Äù).
As a noun for position, the noun has the same etymology above as the verb.

entries.meaning: (golf) The terrain and conditions surrounding the ball before it is struck.
(disc golf) The terrain and conditions surrounding the disc before it is thrown.
(medicine) The position of a fetus in the womb.
A manner of lying; relative position.
An animal's lair.

verbs.description: lie (third-person singular simple present lies, present participle lying, simple past lay or laid, past participle lain or laid or lien) See usage notes.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To rest in a horizontal position on a surface.
examples: The book lies on the table;¬† the snow lies on the roof;¬† he lies in his coffin

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be placed or situated.
(intransitive, copulative) To abide; to remain for a longer or shorter time; to be in a certain state or condition.
examples: to lie waste; to lie fallow; to lie open; to lie hidden; to lie grieving; to lie under one's displeasure; to lie at the mercy of the waves
The paper does not lie smooth on the wall.

entries.meaning: Used with in: to be or exist; to belong or pertain; to have an abiding place; to consist.
examples: He that thinks that diversion may not lie in hard labour, forgets the early rising and hard riding of huntsmen.

entries.meaning: Used with with: to have sexual relations with.
Used with on/upon: to be incumbent (on); to be the responsibility of a person.
(archaic) To lodge; to sleep.
examples: While I was now trifling at home, I saw London,  [‚Ä¶]  where I lay one night only.

entries.meaning: To be still or quiet, like one lying down to rest.
(law) To be sustainable; to be capable of being maintained.
examples: An appeal lies in this case from the ordinary to the arches.

description: From Middle English lien (‚Äúto lie, tell a falsehood‚Äù), from Old English lƒìogan (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *leugan, from Proto-Germanic *leuganƒÖ (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *lewg ∞- (‚Äúto lie, swear, bemoan‚Äù).

Cognate with West Frisian lige (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), Low German legen, l√∂gen (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), Dutch liegen (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), German l√ºgen (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), Norwegian ljuge/lyge (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), Danish lyve (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), Swedish ljuga (‚Äúto lie‚Äù), and more distantly with Bulgarian –ª—ä–∂–∞ (l«é≈æa, ‚Äúto lie‚Äù), Russian –ª–≥–∞—Ç—å (lgat π, ‚Äúto lie‚Äù), –ª–æ–∂—å (lo≈æ π, ‚Äúfalsehood‚Äù).

verbs.description: lie (third-person singular simple present lies, present participle lying, simple past and past participle lied)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To give false information intentionally with intent to deceive.
examples: When Pinocchio lies, his nose grows.
If you are found to have lied in court, you could face a penalty.

While a principle-based approach might claim that lying is always morally wrong, the casuist would argue that, depending upon the details of the case, lying might or might not be illegal or unethical. The casuist might conclude that a person is wrong to lie in legal testimony under oath, but might argue that lying actually is the best moral choice if the lie saves a life.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To convey a false image or impression.
(intransitive, colloquial) To be mistaken or unintentionally spread false information.
examples: Sorry, I haven't seen your keys anywhere...wait, I lied! They're right there on the coffee table.

description: From Middle English lie, from Old English lyƒ°e (‚Äúlie, falsehood‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *lugiz (‚Äúlie, falsehood‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *lewg ∞- (‚Äúto tell lies, swear, complain‚Äù). Cognate with Old Saxon luggi (‚Äúa lie‚Äù), Old High German lugƒ´, lugin (‚Äúa lie‚Äù) (German L√ºge), Danish l√∏gn (‚Äúa lie‚Äù), Bulgarian –ª—ä–∂–∞ÃÅ (l«é≈æ√°, ‚Äú–∞ lie‚Äù), Russian –ª–æ–∂—å (lo≈æ π, ‚Äú–∞ lie‚Äù).

entries.meaning: An intentionally false statement; an intentional falsehood.
examples: Synonyms: alternative fact, bullshit, deception, falsehood, fib, leasing, prevarication; see also Thesaurus:lie
I knew he was telling a lie by his facial expression.

entries.meaning: A statement intended to deceive, even if literally true.
(by extension) Anything that misleads or disappoints.
examples: Wishing this lie of life was o'er.
